awd_abstract_narration: Cotton and his group will continue their research on the                   analysis and numerical simulation of convective storms. They will               focus on multi-scale aspects (organization of convective cells into             lines and clusters, interaction with synoptic scale systems) and on             the genesis of severe weather events (flash floods, strong winds,               tornadoes). The work combines the use of an interactive, nested-                grid model, viz. CSU's Regional Atmospheric Modeling System (RAMS)              with analysis of data gathered by high-resolution observational                 systems, including the CHILL-radar, a national research facility                housed at CSU. The linkage between modelling and observations                   provides iterative testing of hypotheses by numerical simulations,              validation and refinement of the models and objectively analysed                documentation of storms. This last function will depend on four                 dimensional data assimalation procedures (4DDA) to be developed. A              significant element of the planned work lies in new developments in             the RAMS' physics and numerics.                                                                                                                                      Cotton's past record of productivity (in students and public-              ations) foreshadows a significant contribution toward meeting the               demands generated by the U.S. Weather Research Program, and the                 national effort in weather system modernization over the next                   decade.
